ContentClassification.TableReference: Undersöking af Dödligheten enligt Erfarenheten hos Sjutton Svenska Lifförsäkringsbolag. Normaler Risker, 1895-1906 (Stockholm, 1915) reprinted James W. Glover, “United States Life Tables 1890,1901, 1910, and 1901-1910 with Explanatory Text, Mathematical Theory, Computations, Graphs and Original Statistics, also Tables of United States Life Annuities, Life Tables of Foreign Countries, Mortality Tables of Life Insurance Companies”, Department of Commerce, Bureau of the Census (Washington, 1921). Accessed: March, 2014 from http://www.cdc.gov/nchs/data/lifetables/life1890-1910.pdf
ContentClassification.TableDescription: Seventeen Swedish Offices Table - Male. Minimum Age: 15 Maximum Age: 89
ContentClassification.Comments: Study Data: Experience comprises only medically examined, healthy lives for whole life (payable at age 90) and endowment assurances. Data collected for the period 1895 to 1906. No distinction is made between “with profits” and “without profits”. The investigation followed the Austrian method, that is, a person is considered an additional new risk every time he successfully passes another medical examine for insurance. Adopting this practice enabled the Swedish companies to combine their experience. Data kept separate for males and females but only the male data graduated. Methodology: Several methods of graduation were performed by Professor Ivar Fredholm: Makeham curve for each separate year of assurances, graphical method whereby differences of the graduated values were secured, the method adopted by G.F. Hardy in graduating the O^M experience (See SOA Table Identity 254) whereby a “select” table is constructed that joins with an “ultimate” and last, as it appeared a definite select term could not be found, a Makeham-expression was used upon the central death rate. On the whole, the graduation is somewhat low at ages of entry above 50. Data Transcription Errors: None. Data Certified: 10/2013
